editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Madeline Burg

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

note.p: The title page is engraved and signed "Guliel[mus] Hole fecit". The second state of the imprint (see The Library, ser. 6, 8:152-6).

The subsidiary plays each have separate dated title pages. Of these, "Every man out of his humour", "Cynthia's revels", and "Poetaster" have title pages in varying states; see Greg for details. Pagination and register are continuous.
A number of sheets exist in two different settings, and certain of these appear to be reprints done much later; see Greg and "Studies in Bibliography" 40:106-20.
A second volume was published without general title page in 1631.
Reproduction of the original in the British Library.

projectDesc.p: This is a very early release with many imperfections. Contact martinmueller@northwestern.edu for corrections and improvement. For more information about the project go to http://scalablereading.northwestern.edu

editorialDecl.p: These texts have been encoded in TEI Simple, but retain all the structural distinctions found in the TCP texts fron which they were derived. The facs attributes for each pb; and welement provide a link to the EEBO pages images. A list of the NUPOS2 tags with descriptiosn and examples can be found at href="http://morphadorner.northwestern.edu/morphadorner/schemata/nupos2-interpgrp.xml"

div.p: The alchemist. A comedy. Acted in the year 1610. By the King's majesty's servants.

quote.l: Unde priùs nulli velarint tempora musae.

div.head: To the lady, most deserving her name, and blood: Mary, la. Wroth.
div.p: In the age of sacrifices, the truth of religion was not in the greatness, and fat of the offerings, but in the devotion, and zeal of the sacrificers: else, what could a handful of gums have done in the sight of a hecatomb? or, how might I appear at this altar, except with those affections, that no less love the light and witness, than they have the conscience of your virtue? If what I offer bear an acceptable odour, and hold the first strength, it is your value of it, which remembers, where, when, and to whom it was kindled. Otherwise, as the times are, there comes rarely forth that thing, so full of authority, or example, but by assiduity and custom, grows less, and loses. This, yet, safe in your judgement (Which is a Sidney's) is forbidden to speak more; lest it talk, or look like one of the ambitious faces of the time: who, the more they paint, are the less themselves.

closer.signed: Your la: true honourer, Ben Jonson.

list.item: Da. pliant, his sister: a widow.

div.head: The alchemist.
The argument.
div.l: The sickness hot, a master quit, for fear,
His house in town: and left one servant there.
Ease him corrupted, and gave means to know
A cheater, and his punk; who, now brought low,
Leaving their narrow practice, were become
Coseners at large: and, only wanting some
House to set up, with him they hear contract,
Each for a share, and all begin to act.
Much company they draw, and much abuse,
In casting figures, telling fortunes, news,
Selling of flies, flat bawdry, with the stone:
Till it, and they, and all in fume are gone.

div.head: Prologue.
div.l: Fortune, that favours fools, these two short hours
We wish away; both for your sakes, and ours,
Judging spectators: and desire in place,
To th'author justice, to ourselves but grace.
Our scene is London, 'cause we would make known,
No country's mirth is better than our own.
No clime breeds better matter, for your whore,
Bawd, squire, impostor, many persons more,
whose manners, now called humours, feed the stage:
And which have still been subject, for the rage
Or spleen of comic-writers. Though this pen
Did never aim to grieve, but better men;
Howe'er the age, he lives in, doth endure
The vices that she breeds, above their cure.
But, when the wholesome remedies are sweet,
And, in their working, gain, and profit meet,
He hopes to find no spirit so much diseased,
But will, with such fair correctives be pleased.
For here, he doth not fear, who can apply.
If there be any, that will sit so nigh
Unto the stream, to look what it doth run,
They shall find things, they'd think, or wish, were done;
They are so natural follies, but so shown,
As even the doers may see, and yet not own.

sp.l: Believe't, I will.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Thy worst. I fart at thee.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: Have you your wits? Why gentlemen! for love —

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Sirrah, I'll strip you —

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: What to do? lick sigs
Out at my —

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Rogue, rogue, out of all your sleights.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: Nay, look ye! Sovereign, general, are you madmen?

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: O, let the wild sheep lose. I'll gum your silks
With good strong water, an you come.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: Will you have
The neighbours hear you? Will you betray all?
Hark, I hear somebody .

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Sirrah —

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: I shall mar
All that the tailor has made, if you approach.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: You most notorious whelp, you insolent slave.
Dare you do this?

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Yes faith, yes faith.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Why! who
Am I, my mongrel? Who am I?

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: I'll tell you,
Since you know not yourself —

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Speak lower, rogue.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Yes. You were once (Time's not long passed) the good,
Honest, plain, livery-three-pound-thrum; that kept
Your master's worship's house, here, in the friars,
For the vacations —

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Will you be so loud?

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Since, by my means, translated suburb-captain.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: By your means, doctor dog?

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Within man's memory,
All this, I speak of.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Why, I pray you, have I
Been countenanced by you? or you, by me?
Do but collect, sir, where I met you first.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: I do not hear well.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Not of this, I think it.
But I shall put you in mind, sir, at pie-corner.
Taking your meal of steam in, from cook's stalls,
Where, like the father of hunger, you did walk
Piteously costive, with your pinched-horn-nose,
And your complexion, of the roman wash,
Stuck full of black, and melancholic worms,
Like poulder-corns, shot, at th'artillery-yard.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: I wish, you could advance your voice, a little.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: When you went pinned up, in the several rags,
You'd raked, and picked from dunghills, before day,
Your feet in mouldy slippers, for your kibes,
A felt of rug, and a thin threaden cloak,
That scarce would cover your no-buttocks —

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: So, sir!

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: When all your alchemy, and your algebra,
Your minerals, vegetals, and animals,
Your conjuring, cozening, and your dozen of trades,
Could not relieve your corpse, with so much linen
Would make you tinder, but to see a fire;
I ga' you countenance, credit for your coals,
Your stills, your glasses, your materials,
Built you a furnace, drew you customers,
Advanced all your black arts; lent you, beside,
A house to practise in —

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Your master's house?

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Where you have studied the more thriving skill
Of bawdry, since.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Yes, in your master's house.
You, and the rats, here, kept possession.
Make it not strange. I know, ye were one, could keep
The buttery-hatch still locked, and save the chippings,
Sell the dole-beer to aqua-vitae-men,
The which, together with your christmas veils,
At post and pair, your letting out of counters,
Made you a pretty stock, some twenty marks,
And gave you credit, to converse with cobwebs,
Here, since your mistress death hath broke up house.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: You might talk softlier, rascal.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: No, you scarab,
I'll thunder you, in pieces. I will teach you
How to beware, to tempt a fury again
That carries tempest in his hand, and voice.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: The place has made you valiant.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: No, your clothes.
Thou vermin, have I ta'en thee, out of dung,
So poor, so wretched, when no living thing
Would keep thee company, but a spider, or worse?
Raised thee from brooms, and dust, and watering pots?
Sublimed thee, and exalted thee, and fixed thee
I' the third region, called our state of grace?

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: 'Slid, prove today, who shall shark best.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Agreed.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: Yes, and work close, and friendly.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: 'Slight, the knot
Shall grow the stronger, for this breach, with me.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: Why so, my good baboons! Shall we go make
A sort of sober, scurvy, precise neighbours,
(That scarce have smiled twice, sin' the King came in)
A feast of laughter, at our follies? rascals,
Would run themselves from breath, to see me ride,
Or you t'have but a hole, to thrust your heads in,
For which you should pay ear-rent? No, agree.
And may Done Provost ride a feasting, long,
In his old velvet jerkin, and stained scarves,
(My noble sovereign, and worthy general)
Ere we contribute a new cruel garter
To his most worsted worship.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Royal Dol!
Spoken like Claridiana, and thyself!

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: For which, at supper, thou shalt sit in triumph,
And not be styled Dol common, but Dol proper,
Dol singular: the longest cut, at night,
Shall draw thee for his Dol particular.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Who's that? one rings. To the window,

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: Pray heaven,
The master do not trouble us, this quarter.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: O, fear not him. While there dies one, a week,
O'the plague, he's safe, from thinking towards London.
Beside, he's busy at his hop-yards, now:
I had a letter from him. If he do,
He'll send such word, for airing of the house
As you shall have sufficient time, to quit it:
Though we break up a fortnight, 'tis no matter.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Who is it, Dol?

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: A fine young quodling.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: O,
My lawyer's clerk, I lighted on, last night,
In Holborn, at the dagger. He would have
(I told you of him) a familiar,
To rifle with, at horses, and win cups.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: O, let him in.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Stay. Who shall do't?

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Get you
Your robes on. I will meet him, as going out.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: And what shall I do?

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Not be seen, away.
Seem you very reserved.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Enough.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: God b'w'you, sir.
I pray you, let him know that I was here.
His name is Dapper. I would gladly have stayed, but —
Captain, I am here.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Who's that? He's come, I think, doctor.
Good faith, sir, I was going away.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.l: In truth,
I'm very sorry, captain.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: But I thought
Sure, I should meet you.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.l: Ay, I'm very glad.
I'had a scurvy writ, or two, to make,
And I had lent my watch last night, to one
That dines, today, at the sheriffs: and so was robbed
Of my pastime. Is this the cunning-man?

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: This is his worship.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.l: Is he a doctor?

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.l: And ha'you broke with him, captain?

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: I.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.l: And how?

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Faith, he does make the matter, sir, so dainty,
I know not what to say —

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.l: Not so, good captain.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Would I were fairly rid on't, believe me.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.l: Nay, now you grieve me, sir. Why should you wish so?
I dare assure you. I'll not be ungrateful.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: I cannot think you will, sir. But the law
Is such a thing — and then, he says, read's matter
Falling so lately —

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.l: Read? He was an ass,
And dealt, sir, with a fool.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: It was a clerk, sir.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.l: A clerk?

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Nay, hear me, sir, you know the law
Better, I think —

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.l: I should, sir, and the danger.
You know I showed the statute to you?

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: You did so.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.l: And will I tell, then? By this hand, of flesh,
Would it might never wright good court-hand, more,
If I discover. What do you think of me,
That I am a chiause?

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: What's that?

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.l: The Turk was, here —
As one would say, do you think I am a Turk?

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: I'll tell the doctor so.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.l: Do, good sweet captain.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Come, noble doctor, pray thee, let's prevail,
This is the gentleman, and he is no chiause.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Captain, I have returned you all my answer.
I would do much, sir, for your love — but this
I neither may, nor can.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Tut, do not say so.
You deal, now, with a noble fellow, doctor,
One that will thank you, richly, and he's no chiause:
Let that, sir, move you.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Pray you, forbear —

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: He has
Four angels, here —

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: You do me wrong, good sir.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Doctor, wherein? To tempt you, with these spirits?

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: To tempt my art, and love, sir, to my peril.
Before heaven, I scarce can think you are my friend,
Swear by your fac? and in a thing so known
Unto the doctor? How shall we, sir, trust you
I'the other matter? Can we ever think,
When you have won five, or six thousand pound,
You'll send us shares in't, by this rate?

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.l: By Jove, sir,
I'll win ten thousand pound, and send you half.
I-fac's no oath.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: No, no, he did but jest.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Go too. Go, thank the doctor. He's your friend
To take it so.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.l: I thank his worship.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: So?
Another angel.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.l: Must I?

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Must you? 'slight,
What else is thanks? will you be trivial? Doctor,
When must he come, for his familiar?

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.l: Shall I not ha' it with me?

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: O, good sir!
There must a world of ceremonies pass,
You must be bathed, and fumigated, first;
Besides, the Queen of fairy does not rise,
Till it be noon.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Not, if she danced, tonight .

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: And she must bless it.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Did you never see
Her royal grace, yet?

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.l: Whom?

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Your aunt of fairy?

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Not, since she kissed him, in the cradle, captain,
I can resolve you that.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Well, see her grace,
Whate'er it cost you, for a thing that I know!
It will be somewhat hard to compass: but,
However , see her. You are made, believe it,
If you can see her. Her grace is a lone woman,
And very rich, and if she take a fancy,
She will do strange things. See her, at any hand.
'Slid, she may hap to leave you all she has!
It is the doctor's fear.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.l: How will't be done, then?

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Let me alone, take you no thought. Do you
But say to me, captain, I'll see her grace.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.l: one knocks without. captain, I'll see her grace.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Enough.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Who's there?
Anon. (Conduct him forth, by the back way)
Sir, against one o'clock , prepare yourself.
Till when you must be fasting; only, take
Three drops of vinegar, in, at your nose;
Two at your mouth; and one, at either ear;
Then, bathe your fingers ends; and wash your eyes;
To sharpen your five senses; and, cry hum,
Thrice; and then buz, as often; and then, come.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Can you remember this?

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.l: I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Well, then, away. 'tis, but your bestowing
Some twenty nobles, among her grace's servants;
And, put on a clean shirt ▪ you do not know
What grace her grace may do you in clean linen.
Come in (Good wives, I pray you forbear me, now.
Troth I can do you no good, till afternoon)
What is your name, say you, Abel drugger?

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: A seller of tobacco?

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Umh.
Free of the grocers?

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: Ay, an't please you.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Well —
Your business, Abel?

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: This, an't please your worship,
I'm a young beginner, and am building
Of a new shop, an't like your worship; just,
At corner of a street: (Here's the plot on't.)
And I would know, by art, sir, of your worship,
Which way I should make my door, by necromancy.
And, where my shelves. And, which should be for boxes.
And, which for pots. I would be glad to thrive, sir.
And, I was wished to your worship, by a gentleman,
One captain face, that says you know men's planets,
And their good angels, and their bad.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: I do,
If I do see 'em —

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: What! my honest Abel?
Thou art well met, here!

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: Troth, sir, I was speaking,
Just, as your worship came here, of your worship.
I pray you, speak for me to master doctor.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: He shall do any thing. Doctor, do you hear?
This is my friend, Abel, an honest fellow,
He lets me have good tobacco, and he does not
Sophisticate it, with sack-lees, or oil,
Nor washes it in muscadel, and grains,
Nor buries it, in gravel, under ground,
Wrapped up in greasy leather, or pissed clouts:
But keeps it in fine lily-pots, that opened,
Smell like conserve of roses, or French beans.
He has his maple block, his silver tongs,
Winchester pipes, and fire of juniper.
A neat, spruce-honest-fellow, and no goldsmith.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: He's a fortunate fellow, that I am sure on —

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Already, sir, ha' you found it? L' thee Abel!

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: And, in right way toward riches —

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: This summer,
He will be of the clothing of his company:
And, next spring, called to the scarlet. Spend what he can.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: What, and so little beard?

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Sir, you must think,
He may have a receipt, to make hair come.
But he'll be wise, preserve his youth, and fine for't:
His fortune looks for him, another way.
methinks , I see him, entering ordinaries,
Dispensing for the pox; and plaguy-houses,
Reaching his dose; walking morefields for lepers;
And offering citizens-wives pomander-bracelets,
As his preservative, made of the elixir;
Searching the spittle, to make old bawds young;
And the highways, for beggars, to make rich:
I see no end of his labours. He will make
Nature ashamed, of her long sleep: when art,
Who's but a stepdame, shall do more, than she,
In her best love to mankind, ever could.
If his dream last, he'll turn the age, to gold.
Come on, sir. Now, you set your foot on shore
In novo orbe; here's the rich Peru:
And there within, sir, are the golden mines,
Great Salomon's Ophir! He was sailing to't,
Three years, but we have reached it in ten months.
This is the day, wherein, to all my friends,
I will pronounce the happy word, be rich.
This day, you shall be spectatissimi.
You shall no more deal with the hollow die,
Or the frail card. No more be at charge of keeping
The livery-punk, for the young heir, that must
Seal, at all hours, in his shirt. No more
If he deny, ha' him beaten to't, as he is
That brings him the commodity. No more
Shall thirst of satin, or the covetous hunger
Of velvet entrails, for a rude-spun cloak,
To be displayed at madam Augusta's, make
The sons of sword, and hazard fall before
The golden calf, and on their knees, whole nights,
Commit idolatry with wine, and trumpets:
Or go a feasting, after drum and ensign.
No more of this. You shall start up young viceroys,
And have your punks, and punquettees, my surly.
And unto thee, I speak it first, be rich. Within sir.
Where is my Subtle, there? Within hough?
He'll come to you, by and by.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: That's his fire-drake,
His lungs, his Zephyrus, he that puffs his coals,
Till he firk nature up, in her own centre.
You are not faithful, sir. This night, I'll change
All, that is mettle, in thy house, to gold.
And, early in the morning, will I send
To all the plumbers, and the pewterers,
And buy their tin, and lead up: and to Lothbury,
For all the copper.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: What, and turn that too?

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: Yes, and I'll purchase Devonshire, and Cornwall,
And make them perfect Indies! You admire now?

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: No faith.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: But when you see th'effects of the great medicine!
Of which one part projected on a hundred
Of Mercury, or Venus, or the moon,
Shall turn it, to as many of the sun;
Nay, to a thousand, so ad infinitum:
You will believe me.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: Yes, when I see't, I will.
But, if my eyes do cousin me so (And I
Giving 'em no occasion) sure, I'll have
A whore, shall piss 'em out, next day.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: Ha! why?
Do you think, I fable with you? I assure you,
He that has once the flower of the sun,
The perfect ruby, which we call elixir,
Not only can do that; but by it's virtue,
Can confer honour, love, respect, long life,
Give safety, valour: yea, and victory,
To whom he will. In eight, and twenty days,
I'll make an old man, of fourscore, a child.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: No doubt, he's that already.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: Nay, I mean,
Restore his years, renew him, like an eagle,
To the fifth age; make him get sons, and daughters,
Young giants; as our philosophers have done
(The ancient patriarchs afore the flood)
But taking, once a week, on a knife's point,
The quantity of a grain of mustard, of it:
Become stout Mars's, and beget young Cupids.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: The decayed vestals of Pickt-hatch would thank you,
That keep the fire alive, there.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: 'Tis the secret
Of nature, naturized 'gainst all infections,
Cures all diseases, coming of all causes,
A month's grief, in a day; a year's, in twelve:
And, of what age soever, in a month.
Passed all the doses, of your drugging doctors.
I'll undertake, withal, to fright the plague
Out o'the kingdom, in three months.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: And I'll
Be bound, the players shall sing your praises, then,
Without their poets.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: Sir, I'll do't. Mean time,
I'll give away so much, unto my man,
Have a sublimed pure wife, unto that fellow
I'll send a thousand pound, to be my cuckold.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: And I shall carry it?

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: No. I'll ha' no bawds,
But fathers, and mothers. They will do it best.
Best of all others. And, my flatterers
Shall be the pure, and gravest of divines,
That I can get for money. My mere fools,
Eloquent burgesses, and then my poets
The same that writ so subtly of the fart,
Whom I will entertain, still, for that subject.
The few, that would give out themselves, to be
Court, and town-stallions, and, each where, belie
Ladies, who are known most innocent, for them;
Those will I beg, to make me eunuchs of:
And they shall fan me with ten ostrich tails
A piece, made in a plume, to gather wind.
We will be brave, puff, now we ha' the medicine.
My meat, shall all come in, in Indian shells,
Dishes of agate, set in gold, and studded,
With emeralds, sapphires, hyacinths, and rubies.
The tongues of carps, dormice, and camels heels,
Boiled i'the spirit of sol, and dissolved pearl,
(Apicius diet, 'gainst the epilepsy)
And I will eat these broths, with spoons of amber,
Headed with diamant, and carbuncle.
My footboy shall eat pheasants, calvered salmons,
Knots, godwits, lampreys: I myself will have
The beards of barbels, served, in stead of salads;
Oiled mushrooms; and the swelling unctuous paps
Of a fat pregnant sow, newly cut off,
Dressed with an exquisite, and poignant sauce;
For which, I'll say unto my cook, there's gold,
Go forth, and be a knight.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Sir, I'll go look
A little, how it heightens.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: Do. My shirts
I'll have of taffata-sarsnet, soft, and light
As cobwebs; and for all my other raiment
It shall be such, as might provoke the Persian;
Were he to teach the world riot, a new.
My gloves of fishes, and birds-skins, perfumed
With gums of paradise, and Eastern air —

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: And d'ye think to have the stone, with this?

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: No, I do think, t'have all this, with the stone.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: Why, I have heard, he must be homo frugi,
A pious, holy, and religious man,
One free from mortal sin, a very virgin.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: That makes it, sir, he is so. But I buy it.
My venture brings it me. He, honest wretch,
A notable, superstitious, good soul,
Has worn his knees bare, and his slippers bald,
With prayer, and fasting for it: and, sir, let him
Do't alone, for me, still. Here he comes,
Not a profane word, afore him: 'tis poison.
Good morrow, father.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Gentle son, good morrow,
And, to your friend, there. What is he, is with you?

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: An heretic, that I did bring along,
In hope, sir, to convert him.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Son, I doubt
You're covetous, that thus you meet your time
I'the just point: prevent your day, at morning.
This argues something, worthy of a fear
Of importune, and carnal appetite.
Take heed, you do not cause the blessing leave you,
With your ungoverned haste. I should be sorry,
To see my labours, now, e'en at perfection,
Got by long watching, and large patience,
Not prosper, where my love, and zeal hath placed 'em.
Which (Heaven I call to witness, with yourself,
To whom, I have poured my thoughts) in all my ends,
Have looked no way, but unto public good,
To pious uses, and dear charity,
No grown a prodigy with men. Wherein
If you, my son, should now prevaricate,
And, to your own particular lusts, employ
So great, and Catholic a bliss: be sure,
A curse will follow, yea, and overtake
Your subtle, and most secret ways.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: I know, sir,
You shall not need to fear me. I but come,
To ha'you confute this gentleman.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: Who is,
Indeed, sir, somewhat caustive of belief
Towards your stone: would not be gulled.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Well, son,
All that I can convince him in, is this,
The work is done: bright sol is in his robe.
We have a medicine of the triple soul,
The glorified spirit. Thanks be to heaven,
And make us worthy of it. Eulenspiegel .

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Anon, sir.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Look well to the register,
But, much less charity, should I gull myself.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Why, what have you observed, sir, in our art,
Seems so impossible?

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: But your whole work, no more.
That you should hatch gold in a furnace, sir,
As they do eggs, in Egypt!

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Sir, do you
Believe that eggs are hatched so?

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: If I should?

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Why, I think that the greater miracle.
No egg, but differs from a chicken, more,
Than metals in themselves.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: That cannot be.
The egg's ordained by nature, to that end:
And is a chicken in potentia.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: The same we say of lead, and other metals,
Which would be gold, if they had time.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: And that
Our art doth further.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Ay, for 'twere absurd
To think that nature, in the earth, bred gold
Perfect, i' the instant. Something went before.
There must be remote matter.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: Ay, what is that?

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Marry, we say —

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: Ay, now it heats: stand father.
Pound him to dust —

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: It is, of the one part,
A humid exhalation, which we call
Materia liquida, or the unctuous water;
On th'other part, a certain crass, and viscous
Portion of earth; both which, concorporate,
Do make the elementary matter of gold:
Which is not, yet, propria materia,
But common to all metals, and all stones.
For, where it is forsaken of that moisture,
And hath more dryness, it becomes a stone;
Where it retains more of the humid fatness,
It turns to sulphur, or to quicksilver:
Who are the parents of all other metals.
Nor can this remote matter, suddenly,
Progress so from extreme, unto extreme,
As to grow gold, and leap o'er all the means.
Nature doth, first, beget th'imperfect; then
Proceeds she to the perfect. Of that airy,
And oily water, mercury is engendered;
Sulphur o'the fat, and earthy part: the one
(Which is the last) supplying the place of male,
The other of the female, in all metals.
Some do believe hermaphrodeity,
That both do act, and suffer. But, these two
Make the rest ductile, malleable, extensive.
And, even in gold, they are; for we do find
Seeds of them, by our fire, and gold in them:
and can produce the species of each mettle
More perfect thence, than nature doth in earth.
Beside, who doth not see, in daily practice,
Art can beget bees, hornets, beetles, wasps,
Out of the carcases, and dung of creatures;
Yea, scorpions, of an herb, being rightly placed:
And these are living creatures, far more perfect,
And excellent, than metals.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: Well said, father!
Nay, if he take you in hand, sir, with an argument,
He'll bray you in a mortar.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: Pray you, sir, stay.
Rather, then I'll be brayed, sir, I'll believe,
That alchemy is a pretty kind of game,
Somewhat like tricks of the cards, to cheat a man,
With charming.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Sir?

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: What else are all your terms,
Whereon no one o'your writers 'grees with other?
Of your elixir, your lac virgins,
Your stone, your medicine, and your chrysosperm,
Your sal, your sulphur, and your mercury,
Your oil of height, your tree of life, your blood,
Your marchesite, your tutie, your magnesia,
Your toad, your crow, your dragon, and your panther,
Your sun, your moon, your firmament, your adrop,
Your lato, azoch, zernich, chibrit, heautarit,
And then, your red man, and your white woman,
With all your broths, your menstrues, and materials,
Of piss, and eggshells, women's terms, man's blood,
Hair o'the head, burned clouts, chalk, merds, and clay,
Powder of bones, scalings of iron, glass,
And worlds of other strange ingredients,
Would burst a man to name?

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: And all these, named,
Intending but one thing: which art our writers
Used to obscure their art.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: Sir, so I told him,
Because the simple idiot should not learn it,
And make it vulgar.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Was not all the knowledge
Of the Egyptians written in mystic symbols?
Speak not the scriptures, oft, in parables?
Are not the choicest fables of the poets,
That were the fountains, and first springs of wisdom,
Wrapped in perplexed allegories?

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: I urged that,
And cleared to him, that Sisyphus was damned
To roll the ceaseless stone, only, because
He would have made ours common. Dol is seen. who is this?

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: God's precious — what do you mean? Go in, good lady,
Let me entreat you. Where's this varlet?

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Sir?

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: You very knave! do you use me, thus?

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Wherein, sir?
He is their visitor, and does appoint
Who lies with whom; and at what hour; what price;
Which gown; and in what smock; what fall; what tire.
Him, will I prove, by a third person, to find
The subtleties of this dark labyrinth:
Which, if I do discover, dear sir Mammon,
You'll give your poor friend leave, though no philosopher,
To laugh: for you that are, 'tis thought, shall weep.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Sir. He does pray, you'll not forget.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: I will not, sir.
Sir Epicure, I shall leave you?

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: I follow you, straight.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: But do so, good sir, to avoid suspicion.
This gent'man has a parlous head.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: But wilt thou, Ulen,
Be constant to thy promise?

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: As my life, sir.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: And wilt thou insinuate what I am? and praise me?
And say I am a noble fellow?

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: O, what else, sir?
And, that you'll make her royal; with the stone,
An empress; and yourself King of Bantam.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: Wilt thou do this?

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Will I, sir?

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: Lungs, my lungs!
I love thee.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Send your stuff, sir, that my master
May busy himself, about projection.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: Thou'st witched me, rogue: take, go.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Your jack, and all, sir.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: Thou art a villain — I will send my jack;
And the weights too. Slave, I could bite thine ear.
Away, thou dost not care for me.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Not I, sir?

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: Come, I was born to make thee, my good weasel;
Set thee on a bench: and, ha' thee twirl a chain
With the best lords vermin, of'hem all.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Away, sir.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: A count, nay, a count-palatine —

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Good sir, go.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: Shall not advance thee, better: no, nor faster.
Has he bit? Has he bit?

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: And swallowed too, my Subtle.
I ha' given him line, and now he plays, i'faith.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: And shall we twitch him?

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Through both the gills.
A wench is a rare bait, with which a man
No sooner's taken, but he straight firks mad.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Dol, my lord Wha'ts'hum's sister, you must now
Bear yourself statelike.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: O, let me alone.
I'll not forget my race, I warrant you.
I'll keep my distance, laugh, and talk aloud;
Have all the tricks of a proud scurvy lady,
And be as rude as her woman.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Well said, sanguine.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: But will he send his andirons?

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: His jack too;
And's iron shooing-horn: I ha' spoke to him. Well,
I must not lose my wary gamester, yonder.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: O Monsieur caution, that will not be gulled?

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Ay, if I can strike a fine hook into him, now,
The temple-church, there I have cast mine angle.
Well, pray for me. I'll about it.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: What,one knock. more gudgeons!
Dol, scout, scout; stay face, you must go to the door:
Pray god, it be my Anabaptist. Who is't, Dol?

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: I know him not. He looks like a gold-end-man.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: God's so! 'tis he, he said he would send. What call you him?
The sanctified elder, that should deal
For Mammon's jack, and andirons! Let him in.
Stay, help me of, first, with my gown. Away
Madam, to your withdrawing chamber. Now,
In a new tune, new gesture, but old language.
This fellow is sent, from one negotiates with me
About the stone, too; for the holy brothers
Of Amsterdam, the exiled saints: that hope
To raise their discipline, by it. I must use him
In some strange fashion, now, to make him admire me.
Where is my drudge?

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Take away the recipient,
And rectify your menstrue, from the phlegma.
Then power it, o'the sol, in the cucurbite,
And let 'em macerate, together.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Yes, sir.
And save the ground?

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: No. Terra damnata
Must not have entrance, in the work. Who are you?

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: A faithful brother, if it please you.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: What's that?
A lullianist? A Ripley? Filius artis?
Can you sublime, and dulcify? calcine?
Know you the sapour Pontic? sapour slipstick?
Or, what is homogene, or heterogene?

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: I understand no heathen language, truly.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Heathen, you knipper-doling? Is ars sacra,
Or chrysopoeia, or spagirica,
Or the pamphysic, or panarchick knowledge,
A heathen language?

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Heathen greek, I take it.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: How? heathen Greek?

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: All's heathen, but the hebrew.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Sirrah, my varlet, stand you forth, and speak to him
Like a philosopher: answer, i'the language.
Formed in some mystic character; whose radij,
Striking the senses of the passers by,
Shall, by a virtual influence, breed affections,
That may result upon the party owns it:
As thus —

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Nab!

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: He first shall have a bell, that's Abel;
And, by it, standing one, whose name is d'ye,
In a rug gown; there's D. and rug, that's drug:
And, right anent him, a dog snarling er;
There's drugger, Abel drugger. That's his sign.
And here's now mystery, and hieroglyphic!

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Abel, thou art made.

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: Sir, I do thank his worship.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Six o'thy legs more, will not do it, Nab.
He has brought you a pipe of tobacco, doctor.

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: Yes, sir:
I have another thing, I would impart —

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Out with it, Nab.

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: Sir, there is lodged, hard by me,
A rich young widow —

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Good! A bona roba?

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: But nineteen, at the most.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Very good, Abel.

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: Marry, she's not in fashion, yet; she wears
A hood: but 't stands a cop.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: No matter, Abel.

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: And, I do, now and then give her a fucus —

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: What! dost thou deal, Nab?

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: I did tell you, captain.

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: And physic too sometime, sir: for which she trusts me
With all her mind. She's come up here, of purpose
To learn the fashion.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Good (His match too!) on, Nab.

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: And she does strangely long to know her fortune.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: God's lid, Nab, send her to the doctor, hither.

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: Yes, I have spoke to her of his worship, already:
But she's afraid, it will be blown abroad
And hurt her marriage.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Hurt it? 'tis the way
To heal it, if 'twere hurt; to make it more
Followed, and sought: Nab, thou shalt tell her this.
She'll be more known, more talked of, and your widows
Are ne'er of any price till they be famous;
Their honour is their multitude of suitors:
Send her, it may be thy good fortune. What?
Thou dost not know.

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: No, sir, she'll never marry
Under a knight. Her brother has made a vow.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: What, and dost thou despair, my little Nab,
Knowing, what the doctor has set down for thee,
And, seeing so many, o'the city, dubbed?
One glass o'thy water, with a madam, I know,
Will have it done,

sp.speaker: Nab.
sp.l: What's her brother? A knight?

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: No, sir, a gentleman, newly warm in his land, sir,
Scarce cold in his one and twenty; that does govern
His sister, here: and is a man himself
of some three thousand a year, and is come up
To learn to quarrel, and to live by his wits,
And will go down again, and die i' the country.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: How! to quarrel?

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: Yes, sir, to carry quarrels,
As gallants do, and manage 'em, by line.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: 'Slid, Nab! The doctor is the only man
In Christendom for him. He has made a table,
With mathematical demonstrations,
Touching the art of quarrels. He will give him
An instrument to quarrel by. Go, bring 'em, both:
Him, and his sister. And, for thee, with her
The doctor haply may persuade. Go to.
Shalt give his worship, a new damask suit
Upon the premises.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: O, good captain.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: He shall,
He is the honestest fellow, doctor. Stay not,
No offers, bring the damask, and the parties.

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: I'll try my power, sir.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: And thy will too, Nab.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: 'Tis good tobacco this! What is't an ounce?

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: He'll send you a pound, doctor.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: O, no.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: He will do't.
It is the goodest soul. Abel, about it.
(Thou shalt know more anon. Away, be gone.)
A miserable rogue, and lives with cheese,
And has the worms. That was the cause indeed
Why he came now. He dealt with me, in private,
To get a medicine for 'em.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: And shall, sir. This works.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: A wife, a wife, for one on'us, my dear Subtle:
We'll e'en draw lots, and he, that fails, shall have
The more in goods, the other has in tail.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Rather the less. For she may be so light
She may want grains.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Ay, or be such a burden,
A man would scarce endure her, for the whole.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Faith, best let's see her first, and then determine.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Content. But Dol must ha' no breath on't.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Mum.
Away, you to your surly yonder, catch him.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Pray god, I ha' not stayed too long.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: I fear it.
These chastisements are common to the saints,
And such rebukes we of the separation
Must bear, with willing shoulders, as the trials
Sent forth, to tempt our frailties.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: In pure zeal,
I do not like the man: he is a heathen.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: And, then, the turning of this lawyer's pewter
To plate, at Christmas —

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Christ-tide, I pray you.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Yet, Ananias?

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: I have done.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Or changing
His parcel guilt, to massy gold. You cannot
But raise you friends. With all, to be of power
To pay an army, in the field, to buy
The King of France, out of his realms; or Spain;
Out of his Indies: what can you not do,
Against lords spiritual, or temporal,
That shall oppone you?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: Verily, 'tis true.
We may be temporal lords, ourselves, I take it.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: You may be any thing, and leave off to make
Long-winded exercises: or suck up,
Your ha, and hum, in a tune. I not deny,
But such as are not graced, in a state,
May, for their ends, be adverse in religion,
And get a tune, to call the flock together:
For (To say sooth) a tune does much, with women,
And other phlegmatic people, it is your bell.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Bells are profane: a tune may be religious.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: No warning with you? Then, farewell my patience.
'Slight, it shall down: I will not be thus tortured.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: I pray you, sir.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: All shall perish. I have spoke it.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: Let me find grace, sir, in your eyes; the man
He stands corrected: neither did his zeal
(But as yourself) allow a tune, somewhere.
Which, now, being toward the stone, we shall not need.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: No, nor your holy vizard, to win widows
To give you legacies; or make zealous wives
To rob their husbands, for the common cause:
Nor take the start of bonds, broke but one day,
And say, they were forfeited, by providence.
Nor shall you need, o'ernight to eat huge meals,
To celebrate your next days fast the better:
The whilst the brothers, and the sisters, humbled,
Abate the stiffness of the flesh. Nor cast
Before your hungry hearers, scrupulous bones,
As whether a christian may hawk, or hunt;
Or whether, matrons, of the holy assembly,
May lay their hair out, or wear doublets:
Or have that idol starch, about their linen.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: It is, indeed, an idol.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: Mind him not, sir.
I do command thee, spirit (Of zeal, but trouble)
To peace within him. Pray you, sir, go on.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Nor shall you need to libel 'gainst the prelates,
and shorten so your ears, against the hearing
Of the next wire-drawn grace. Nor, of necessity,
Rail against plays, to please the alderman,
Whose daily custard you devour. Nor lie
With zealous rage, till you are hoarse. Not one
Of these so singular arts. Nor call yourselves,
By names of tribulation, persecution,
Restraint, long-patience, and such like, affected
By the whole family, or wood of you,
Only for glory, and to catch the ear
Of the disciple.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: Truly, sir, they are
Ways, that the godly brothers have invented
For propagation of the glorious cause,
As very notable means, and whereby, also,
Themselves grow soon, and profitably famous.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: O, but the stone, all's idle to't! nothing!
The art of angels, nature's miracle,
The divine secret, that doth fly in clouds,
From East to West: and whose tradition
Is not from men, but spirits.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: I hate traditions:
I do not trust them —

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: Peace.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: They are popish, all.
I will not peace. I will not —

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: Ananias.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Please the profane, to grieve the godly: I may not.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Well, Ananias, thou shalt overcome.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: It is an ignorant zeal, that haunts him, sir.
But truly, else, a very faithful brother,
A butcher: and a man, by revelation,
That hath a competent knowledge of the truth.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Has he a competent sum, there, i' the bag,
To buy the goods, within? I am made guardian,
And must, for charity, and conscience' sake,
Now, see the most be made, for my poor orphan:
Though I desire the brothers, too, good gainers.
There, they are, within. When you have viewed, and bought 'em,
And ta'en the inventory of what they are,
They are ready for projection; there's no more
To do: cast on the medicine, so much silver
As there is tin there, so much gold as brass,
I'll gi' it you in, by weight.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: But how long time,
Sir, must the saints expect, yet?

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Let me see,
How's the moon, now? Eight, nine, ten days hence
He will be silver potate; then, three days,
Before he citronise: some fifteen days,
The magisterium will be perfected.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: About the second day, of the third week,
in the ninth month?

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Yes, my good Ananias.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: What will the orphans goods arise to, think you?

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Some hundred marks; as much as filled three cars,
Unloaded now: you'll make six millions of 'em.
But I must ha' more coals laid in.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: How!

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Another load,
And then we ha' finished. We must now increase
Our fire to ignis Arden's, we are passed
Fimus equinus, balnei, cineris,
And all those lenter heats. If the holy purse
Should, with this draught, fall low, and that the saints
Do need a present sum, I have trick
To melt the pewter, you shall buy now, instantly,
And, with a tincture, make you as good Dutch dollars,
As any are in holland.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: Can you so?

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Ay, and shall bide the third examination.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: It will be joyful tidings to the brothers.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: But you must carry it, secret.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: Ay, but stay,
This act of coining, is it lawful?

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Lawful?
We know no magistrate. Or, if we did,
This's foreign coin.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: It is no coining, sir.
It is but casting.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: Ha? you distinguish well.
Casting of money may be lawful.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: 'Tis, sir.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: Truly, I take it so.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: There is no scruple,
Sir, to be made of it; believe Ananias:
This case of conscience he is studied in.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: I'll make a question of it, to the brothers.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: The brothers shall approve it lawful, doubt not.
Where shall't be done?

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: For that we'll talk, anon.
Knock without. there's some to speak with me. Go in, I pray you,
And view the parcels. That's the inventory.
I'll come to you straight. Who is it? Face! Appear.
How now? Good prize?

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Good pox! Yonder caustive cheater
Never came on.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: How then?

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: I ha' walked the round,
Till now, and no such thing.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: And ha' you quit him?

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Quit him? and hell would quit him too, he were happy.
'Slight would you have me stalk like a mill-jade.
All day, for one, that will not yield us grains?
I know him of old.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: O, but to ha' gulled him,
Had been a mastery.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Let him go, black boy,
And turn thee, that some fresh news may possess thee.
A noble count, a don of Spain (My dear
Delicious compeer, and my party-bawd)
Who is come hither, private, for his conscience,
And brought munition with him, six great slops,
Bigger than three Dutch hoighs, beside round trunks,
Furnished with pistolets, and pieces of eight,
Will straight be here, my rogue, to have thy bath
(That is the colour,) and to make his battery
Upon our Dol, our castle, our cinqueport,
Our Dover pire, our what thou wilt. Where is she?
She must prepare perfumes, delicate linen,
The bath in chief, a banquet, and her wit,
For she must milk his Epididimis.
Where is the doxy?

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: I'll send her to thee:
And but dispatch my brace of little John Leyden's,
And come again myself.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Are they within then?

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Numbering the sum.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: How much?

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: A hundred marks, boy.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Why, this's a lucky day! Ten pounds of Mammon!
Three of my clerk! A portague of my grocer!
This of the brothers! beside reversions,
And states, to come i' the widow, and my count!
My share, today, will not be bought for forty —

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Pounds, dainty Dorothy, art thou so near?

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: Yes, say lord general, how fares our camp?

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: As, with the few, that had entrenched themselves
Safe, by their discipline, against a world, Dol:
And laughed, within those trenches, and grew fat
With thinking on the booties, Dol, brought in
Daily, by their small parties. This dear hour,
A doughty don is taken, with my Dol;
And thou mayst make his ransom, what thou wilt,
My Dousabell: he shall be brought here, fettered
With thy fair looks, before he see's thee; and thrown
In a downbed, as dark as any dungeon;
Where thou shalt keep him waking, with thy drum;
Thy drum, my Dol; thy drum; till he be tame
As the poor blackbirds were i' the great frost,
Or bees are with a basin: and so hive him
I' the swanskin coverlid, and cambric sheets,
Till he work honey, and wax, my little gods-gift.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: What is he, general?

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: An Adalantado,
A grandee, girl. Was not my dapper here, yet?

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Nor my drugger?

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: Neither.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: A pox on 'em.
They are so long a furnishing! Such stinkards
Would not be seen, upon these festival days.
And gallants, yet. Here's a young gentleman,
Is born to nothing, forty marks a year,
Which I count nothing. He's to be initiated,
And have a fly o'the doctor. He will win you
By unresistable luck, within this fortnight,
Enough to buy a barony. They will set him
Upmost, at the groom-porters, all the Christmas!
And, for the whole year through, at every place,
Where there is play, present him with the chair;
The best attendance, the best drink, sometimes
Two glasses of canary, and pay nothing;
The purest linen, and the sharpest knife,
The partridge next his trencher: and, somewhere,
The dainty bed, in private, with the dainty.
You shall ha' your ordinaries bid for him,
As playhouses for a poet; and the master
Pray him, aloud, to name what dish he affects,
Which must be buttered shrimps: and those that drink
To no mouth else, will drink to his, as being
The goodly, precedent mouth of all the board.

sp.speaker: Kas.
sp.l: Do you not gull one?

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: 'Od's my life! Do you think it?
You shall have a cast commander, (Can but get
In credit with a glover, or a spurrier,
For some two pair, of either's ware, aforehand)
Will, by most swift posts, dealing with him,
Arrive at competent means, to keep himself,
His punk, and naked boy, in excellent fashion.
And be admired for't.

sp.speaker: Kas.
sp.l: Will the doctor teach this?

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: He will do more, sir, when your land is gone,
(As men of spirit hate to keep earth long (
In a vacation, when small money is stirring,
And ordinaries suspended till the term,
He'll show a perspective, where on one side
You shall behold the faces, and the persons
Of all sufficient young heirs, in town,
Whose bonds are currant for commodity;
On th'other side, the merchant's forms, and others,
(That, without help of any second broker,
(Who would expect a share) will trust such parcels:
In the third square, the very street, and sign
Where the commodity dwells, and does but wait
To be delivered, be it pepper, soap,
Hops, or tobacco, oatmeal, woad, or cheeses.
All which you may so handle, to enjoy,
To your own use, and never stand obliged.

sp.speaker: Kas.
sp.l: I'faith! Is he such a fellow?

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Why, Nab here knows him.
And then for making matches, for rich widows,
Young gentlewomen, heirs, the fortunat'st man!
He's sent too, far, and near, all over England,
To have his counsel, and to know their fortunes.

sp.speaker: Kas.
sp.l: God's will, my sister shall see him.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: I'll tell you, sir,
What he did tell me of Nab. It's a strange thing!
(By the way you must eat no cheese, Nab, it breeds melancholy:
And that same melancholy breeds worms) but pass it,
He told me, honest Nab, here, was ne'er at tavern,
But once in's life!

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: Truth, and no more I was not.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: And, than he was so sick —

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: Could he tell you that, too?

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: How should I know it?

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: In troth we had been a shooting,
And had a piece of fat ram-mutton, to supper,
That lay so heavy of my stomach —

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: And he has no head
To bear any wine; for, what with the noise of the fiddlers,
And care of his shop, for he dares keep no servants —

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: My head did so ache —

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: As he was fain to be brought home,
The doctor told me. And then, a good old woman —

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: (Yes faith, she dwells in Sea-coal-lane) did cure me,
With sodden ale, and pellitory of the wall:
Cost me but two pence. I had another sickness,
Was worse than that.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Ay, that was with the grief
Thou tookest for being 'sessed at eighteen pence,
For the waterwork.

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: In truth, and it was like
T'have cost me almost my life.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Thy hair went off?

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: Yes, sir, 'twas done for spite.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Nay, so says the doctor.

sp.speaker: Kas.
sp.l: Pray thee, tobacco-boy, go fetch my sister,
I'll see this learned boy, before I go:
And so shall she.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Sir, he is busy now:
But, if you have a sister to fetch hither,
Perhaps, your own pains may command her sooner;
And he, by that time, will be free.

sp.speaker: Kas.
sp.l: I go.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Drugger, she's thine: the damask. (Subtle, and I
Must wrestle for her.) Come on, master dapper.
You see, how I turn clients, here, away,
To give your cause dispatch. Ha'you performed
The ceremonies were enjoined you?

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.l: Yes, of the vinegar,
And the clean shirt.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: 'Tis well: that shirt may do you
More worship than you think. Your ant's a fire
But that she will not show it, t'have a sight on you.
Ha'you provided for her grace's servants?

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.l: Yes, here are sixscore Edward shillings.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Good.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.l: And an old Harry's sovereign.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Very good.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.l: And three James shillings, and an Elizabeth groat,
O, sir, you're come i' the only, finest time —

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: Where's master?

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Now preparing for projection, sir.
Your stuff will b' all changed shortly.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: Into gold?

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: To gold, and silver, sir.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: Silver, I care not for.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Yes, sir, a little to give beggars.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: Where's the lady?

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: At hand, here. I ha' told her such brave things, of you,
Touching your bounty and your noble spirit —

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: Hast thou?

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: As she is almost in her fit to see you.
But, good sir, no divinity i' your conference,
For fear of putting her in rage —

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Six men will not hold her down. And, than
If the old man should hear, or see you —

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: Fear not.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: The very house, sir, would run mad. You know it
How scrupulous he is, and violent,
'Gainst the least act of sin. Physick, or mathematics,
Poetry, state, or bawdry (As I told you)
She will endure, and never startle: but
No word of controversy.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: I am schooled, good Ulen.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: And you must praise her house, remember that,
And her nobility.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: Let me, alone:
No herald, no nor antiquary, lungs,
Shall do it better. Go.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Why, this is yet
A kind of modern happiness, to have
Dol common for a great lady.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: Now, Epicure,
Heighten thyself, talk to her, all in gold;
Rain her as many showers, as Jove did drops
Unto his Danae: show the God a miser,
Compared with Mammon. What? the stone will do't.
She shall feel gold, taste gold, hear gold, sleep gold:
Nay, we will concumbere gold. I will be puissant,
And mighty in my talk to her! Here she comes.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: To him, Dol, suckle him. This is the noble knight,
I told your ladyship —

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: Madam, with your pardon,
I kiss your vesture.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: Sir, I were uncivil
If I would suffer that, my lip to you, sir.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: I hope, my lord your brother be in health, lady?

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: My lord, my brother is, though I no lady, sir.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: (Well said my guinea-bird.)

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: Right noble madam —

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: (Oh, we shall have most fierce idolatry!)

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: 'Tis your prerogative.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: Rather your courtesy.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: Were there naught else t'enlarge your virtues, to me,
These answers speak your breeding, and your blood ▪

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: Blood we boast none, sir, a poor baron's daughter.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: Poor! and got you? Profane not. Had your father
Slept all the happy remnant of his life
After that act, lyen but there still, and panted,
He had done enough, to make himself, his issue,
And his posterity noble.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: Sir, although
We may be said to want the guilt, and trappings,
The dress of honour; yet we strive to keep
The seeds, and the materials.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: I do see
The old ingredient, virtue, was not lost,
Nor the drug money, used to make your compound.
There is a strange nobility, i' your eye,
This lip, that chin! Methinks you do resemble
One of the austrian princes.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Very like,
Her father was an Irish costermonger.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: The house of Valois, just, had such a nose.
And such a forehead, yet, the Medici
Of Florence boast.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: Troth, and I have been likened
To all these princes.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: I'll be sworn, I heard it.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: I know not how! it is not any one,
But e'en the very choice of all their features.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: I'll in, and laugh.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: A certain touch, or air,
That sparkles a divinity, beyond
An earthly beauty!

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: O, you play the courtier.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: Good lady, give me leave —

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: In faith, I may not,
To mock me, sir.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: To burn i' this sweet flame:
The phoenix never knew a nobler death.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: Nay, now you court the courtier: and destroy
What you would build. This art, sir, i' your words,
Calls your whole faith in question.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: By my soul —

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: Nay, oaths are made of the same air, sir.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: Nature
Never bestowed upon mortality,
A more unblamed, a more harmonious feature:
She played the stepdame in all faces, else.
Sweet madam, le' me be particular —

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: Particular, sir? I pray you, know your distance.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: In no ill sense, sweet lady, but to ask
How your fair graces pass the hours? I see
You're lodged, here, i' the house of a rare man,
An excellent artist: but, what's that to you?

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: Yes, sir. I study here the mathematics,
And distillation.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: O, I cry your pardon.
He is a divine instructor! can extract
Dost thou not laugh?

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Yes. Are they gone?

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: All's clear.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: The widow is come.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: And your quarrelling disciple?

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: I.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: I must to my captainship again, then.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Stay, bring 'em in, first.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: So I meant. What is she?
A bony-bell?

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: I know not.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: We'll draw lots,
You'll stand to that?

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: What else?

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: O, for a suit,
To fall now, like a curtain: flap.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: To th'door, man.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: You'll ha' the first kiss, 'cause I am not ready.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Yes, and perhaps hit you through both the nostrils.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Who would you speak with?

sp.speaker: Kas.
sp.l: Where's the captain?

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Gone, sir,
About some business.

sp.speaker: Kas.
sp.l: Gone?

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: He'll return straight.
But master doctor, his lieutenant, is here.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Come near, my worshipful boy, my terrae fili,
That is, my boy of land; make thy approaches:
Welcome, I know thy lusts, and thy desires,
And I will serve, and satisfy 'em. Begin,
Charge me from thence, or thence, or in this line;
Here is my centre: ground thy quarrel.

sp.speaker: Kas.
sp.l: You lie.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: How, child of wrath, and anger! the loud lie?
For what, my sudden boy?

sp.speaker: Kas.
sp.l: Nay, that look you too,
I am aforehand.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: O, this's no true grammar,
And as ill logic! You must render causes, child,
Your first, and second intentions, know your canons,
And your divisions, moods, degrees, and differences,
Your predicaments, substance, and accident,
Series extern, and intern, with their causes
Efficient, material, formal, final,
And ha' your elements perfect —

sp.speaker: Kas.
sp.l: What is this!
The angry tongue he talks in?

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: That false precept,
Of being aforehand, has deceived a number;
And made 'em enter quarrels, oftentimes,
Before they were aware: and, afterwards,
Against their wills.

sp.speaker: Kas.
sp.l: How must I do then, sir?

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: I cry this lady mercy. She should, first,
Have been saluted. I do call you lady,
Because you are to be one, ere't be long,
he kisses her. my soft, and buxom widow.

sp.speaker: Kas.
sp.l: Is she, i'faith?

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Yes, or my art is an egregious liar.

sp.speaker: Kas.
sp.l: How know you?

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: By inspection, on her forehead,
and subtlety of her lip,he kisses her again. which must be tasted
Often, to make a judgement. 'slight, she melts
Like a myrobalane! Here is, yet, a line
In rivo frontis, tells me, he is no knight.

sp.speaker: Pli.
sp.l: What is he then, sir?

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Let me see your hand.
O, your linea fortunae makes it plain;
And stella, here, in monte veneris:
But, most of all, iunctura annularis.
He is a soldier, or a man of art, lady:
But shall have some great honour, shortly.

sp.speaker: Pli.
sp.l: Brother,
He's a rare man, believe me!

sp.speaker: Kas.
sp.l: Hold your peace.
Here comes the tother rare man. 'save you captain.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Good master Kastril. Is this your sister?

sp.speaker: Kas.
sp.l: Ay, sir.
Please you to kiss her, and be proud to know her?

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: I shall be proud to know you, lady.

sp.speaker: Pli.
sp.l: Brother,
He calls me lady, too.

sp.speaker: Kas.
sp.l: Ay, peace. I heard it.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: The count is come.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Where is he?

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: At the door.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Why, you must entertain him.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: What'll you do
With these the while?

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Why, have 'em up, and show 'em
Some fustian book, or the dark glass.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Before god,
She is a delicate dabchick! I must have her.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Must you? Ay, if your fortune will, you must.
Come sir, the captain will come to us presently.
I'll ha' you to my chamber of demonstrations,
Where I'll show you both the grammar, and logic,
And rhetoric of quarrelling; my whole method,
Drawn out in tables: and my instrument,
That hath the several scale upon't, shall make you
Able to quarrel, at a straw's breadth, by moonlight.
And, lady, I'll have you look in a glass,
Some half an hour, but to clear your eyesight,
Against you see your fortune: which is greater,
Than I may judge upon the sudden, trust me.
Where are you, doctor?

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: I'll come to you presently ▪

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: I will ha' this same widow, now I ha' seen her,
On any composition.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: What do you say?

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Have you disposed of them?

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: I ha' sent 'em up.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Subtle, in troth, I needs must have this widow.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Is that the matter?

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Nay, but hear me.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Go to,
If you rebel once, Dol shall know it all.
And scrubbed, and fubbed, dear don, before you go.
You shall, in faith, my scurvy baboon don:
Be curried, clawed, and flawed, and tawed, indeed.
I will the heartilier go about it now,
And make the widow a punk, so much the sooner,
To be revenged on this impetuous face:
The quickly doing of it is the grace.

div.head: Act iv. Scene iiii.
div.stage: Face, Kastril, Da. Pliant, Subtle, svrly.

sp.l: Come lady: I knew, the doctor would not leave,
Till he had found the very nick of her fortune.

sp.speaker: Kas.
sp.l: To be a countess, say you? A Spanish countess, sir.

sp.speaker: Pli.
sp.l: Why? is that better than an English countess?

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Better? 'slight, make you that a question, lady?

sp.speaker: Kas.
sp.l: Nay, she is a fool, captain, you must pardon her.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Ask from your courtier, to your inns of courtman,
To your mere milliner: they will tell you all,
Your Spanish jennet is the best horse. Your Spanish
Stoop is the best garb. Your Spanish beard
Is the best cut. Your Spanish ruffs are the best
Wear. Your Spanish pavin the best dance.
Your Spanish titillation in a glove
The best perfume. And, for your Spanish pike,
And Spanish blade, let your poor captain speak.
Here comes the doctor.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: My most honoured lady,
(For so I am now to style you, having found
By this my scheme, you are to undergo
An honourable fortune, very shortly.)
What will you say now, if some —

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: I ha' told her all, sir.
And her right worshipful brother, here, that she shall be
A countess: do not delay 'em, sir. A Spanish countess.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Still, my scarce worshipful captain, you can keep
No secret. Well, since he has told you, madam,
Do you forgive him, and I do.

sp.speaker: Kas.
sp.l: She shall do that, sir.
I'll look to't, 'tis my charge.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Well then. Naught rests
But that she fit her love, now, to her fortune.

sp.speaker: Pli.
sp.l: Truly, I shall never brook a Spaniard.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: No?

sp.speaker: Pli.
sp.l: Never, sin' eighty-eight could I abide 'em,
And that was some three year afore I was born, in truth.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Come, you must love him, or be miserable:
Choose, which you will.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: By this good rush, persuade her,
she will cry strawberries else, within this twelvemonth.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Nay, shads, and mackerel, which is worse.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Indeed, sir?

sp.speaker: Kas.
sp.l: God's lid, you shall love him, or I'll kick you.

sp.speaker: Pli.
sp.l: Why?
I'll do as you will ha' me, brother.

sp.speaker: Kas.
sp.l: Do,
Or by this hand, I'll maul you.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Nay, good sir,
Be not so fierce.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: No, my enraged child,
She will be ruled. What, when she comes to taste
The pleasures of a countess! to be courted —

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: And kissed, and ruffled!

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Ay, behind the hangings.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: And then come forth in pomp!

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: And know her state!

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Of keeping all th'idolaters of the chamber
Barer to her, then at their prayers!

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Is served
Upon the knee!

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: And has her pages, ushers,
Footmen, and coaches —

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Her six mares —

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Nay, eight!

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: To hurry her through London, to th'exchange,
Bedlam, the china-houses —

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Yes, and have
The citizens gape at her, and praise her tires!
And my-lords goose-turd bands, that rides with her!

sp.speaker: Kas.
sp.l: Most brave! By this hand, you are not my sister,
If you refuse.

sp.speaker: Pli.
sp.l: I will not refuse, brother.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: Que es esto, sennores, que non se venga?
Esta tardanza me mata!

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: It is the count come!
The doctor knew he would be here, by his art.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: En gallanta madama, don! gallantissima!

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: Por tódos los dioses, la mas acabada
Hermosura, que he visto en mi vida!

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Is't not a gallant language, that they speak?

sp.speaker: Kas.
sp.l: An admirable language! Is't not French?

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: No, Spanish, sir.

sp.speaker: Kas.
sp.l: It goes like law-french,
And that, they say, is the court-liest language.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: List, sir.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: El sol ha perdido su lumbre, con el
Resplandor, que tràe esta dama. Valga me dios!

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: He 'Admires your sister.

sp.speaker: Kas.
sp.l: Must not she make curtsy?

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: 'Ods will, she must go to him, man; and kiss him!
It is the Spanish fashion, for the women
To make first court.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: 'Tis true he tells you, sir:
His art knows all.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: Por que no se acùde?

sp.speaker: Kas.
sp.l: He speaks to her, I think?

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: That he does sir.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: Por el amor de dios, que es esto, que se tàrda?

sp.speaker: Kas.
sp.l: Nay, see: she will not understand him! Gull.
Noddy.

sp.speaker: Pli.
sp.l: What say you brother?

sp.speaker: Kas.
sp.l: Ass, my sister,
Go kiss him, as the cunning man would ha' you,
I'll thrust a pin i' your buttocks else.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: O, no sir.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: Sennora mia, mi persona muy indigna esta
All gar à tànta hermosura.
A peck of coals, or so, which is cold comfort, sir.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: O my voluptuous mind! I am justly punished.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: And so am I, sir.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: Cast from all my hopes —

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Nay, certainties, sir.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: By mine own base affections.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Subtle seems come to himself. o, the cursed fruits of vice, and lust!

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: Good father,
It was my sin. Forgive it.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Hangs my roof
Over us still, and will not fall, o justice,
Upon us, for this wicked man!

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Nay, look, sir,
You grieve him, now, with staying in his sight:
Good sir, the noble man will come too, and take you,
And that may breed a tragedy.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: I'll go.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Ay, and repent at home, sir. It may be,
For some good penance, you may ha' it, yet,
A hundred pound to the box at bedlam —

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: For the restoring such as ha' their wits.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: I'll do't.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: I'll send one to you to receive it.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: Do.
Is no projection left?

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: All flown, or stinks, sir.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: Will naught be saved, that's good for medicine, thinkst thou?

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: I cannot tell, sir. There will be, perhaps,
Something, about the scraping of the shards,
Will cure the itch: though not your itch of mind, sir.
It shall be saved for you, and sent home. Good sir,
This way: for fear the lord should meet you.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Face.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: I.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Is he gone?

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Yes, and as heavily
As all the gold he hoped for, were in his blood.
Let us be light, though.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Ay, as balls, and bound
And hit our heads against the roof for joy:
There's so much of our care now cast away.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Now to our don.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Yes, your young widow, by this time
Is made a countess, face: she has been in travail
Of a young heir for you.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Good, sir.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Off with your case,
And greet her kindly, as a bridegroom should,
After these common hazards.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Very well, sir.
Will you go fetch don Diego off, the while?

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: And fetch him over too, if you'll be pleased, sir:
Would Dol were in her place, to pick his pockets now.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Why, you can do it as well, if you would set to't.
I pray you prove your virtue.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: For your sake, sir.
Lady, you see into what hands, you are fallen;
Amongst what a nest of villains! and how near
Your honour was t'have catched a certain clap
(Through your credulity) had I but been
So punctually forward, as place, time,
And other circumstance would ha' made a man:
For you're a handsome woman: would ye were wise, too.
I am a gentleman, come here disguised,
Only to find the knaveries of this citadel,
And where I might have wronged your honour, and have not,
I claim some interest in your love. You are,
They say, a widow, rich: and I am a bachelor,
Worth naught: your fortunes may make me a man,
As mine ha' preserved you a woman. Think upon it,
And whether, I have deserved you, or no.

sp.speaker: Pli.
sp.l: I will, sir.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: And for these household-rogues, let me alone,
To treat with them.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: How doth my noble Diego?
And my dear madam, countess? Hath the count
Been courteous, lady? liberal? and open?
Donzell, methinks you look melancholic,
After your coitum, and scurvy! Truly,
I do not like the dulness of your eye:
It hath a heavy cast, 'tis upsee Dutch,
And says you are a lumpish whoremaster.
Be lighter,he falls to picking of them. I will make your pockets so.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: Will you, don bawd, and pickpurse? How now? Reel you?
Stand up sir, you shall find since I am so heavy,
I'll give you equal weight.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Help, murder!

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: No, sir.
There's no such thing intended. A good cart,
And a clean whip shall ease you of that fear.
I am the Spanish don, that should be cozened,
Do you see? cozened? Where's your captain face?
That parcel-broker, and whole-bawd, all rascal.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: How, surly!

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: O, make your approach, good captain.
I've found, from whence your copper rings, and spoons
Come, now, wherewith you cheat abroad in taverns.
'Twas here, you learned t'anoint your boot with brimstone,
Then rub men's gold on't, for a kind of touch,
And say 'twas naught, when you had changed the colour,
That you might have't for nothing? And this doctor,

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: I know not, Nab: thou shalt, if I can help it.
Hieronymo's old cloak, ruff, and hat will serve,
Subtle hath whispered with him this while. I'll tell thee more, when thou bringst 'em.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Sir, I know
The Spaniard hates the brothers, and hath spies
Upon their actions: and that this was one
I make no scruple. But the holy synod
Have been in prayer, and meditation, for it.
And 'tis revealed no less, to them, then me,
That casting of money is most lawful.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: True.
But here, I cannot do it; if the house
Should chance to be suspected, all would out,
And we be locked up, in the tower, for ever,
To make gold there (For th'state) never come out:
And, then, are you defeated.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: I will tell
This to the elders, and the weaker brothers,
That the whole company of the separation
May join in humble prayer again.

sp.speaker: (Sub.
sp.l: And fasting.)

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Yea, for some fitter place. The peace of mind
Rest with these walls.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Thanks, courteous Ananias.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: What did he come for?

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: About casting dollars,
Presently, out of hand. And so, I told him,
A Spanish minister came here to spy,
Against the faithful —

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: I conceive. Come Subtle,
Thou art so down upon the least disaster!
How wouldst thou ha' done, if I had not helped thee out?

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: I thank thee face, for the angry boy, i'faith.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Who would ha' looked, it should ha' been that rascal?
Surly? He had died his beard, and all. Well, sir,
Here's damask come, to make you a suit.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Where's drugger?

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: He is gone to borrow me a Spanish habit,
I'll be the count, now.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: But where's the widow?

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Within, with my lord's sister: madam Dol
Is entertaining her.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: By your favour, face,
Now she is honest, I will stand again.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: You will not offer it?

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: Why?

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Stand to your word,
Or — here comes

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: She knows —

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: You're tyrannous still.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Strict for my right. How now, Dol? Hast told her,
The Spanish count will come?

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: Yes, but another is come,
You little looked for!

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Who's that?

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: Your master:
The master of the house.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: How, Dol!

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: She lies.
This is some trick. Come, leave your quiblins, Dorothy.

sp.speaker: Dol.
