sp.l: Look out, and see.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Art thou in earnest?

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: 'Slight,
Forty of the neighbours are about him, talking.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: 'Tis he, by this good day.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: 'Twill prove ill day,
For some on us.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: We are undone, and taken.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: Lost, I'm afraid.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: You said he would not come,
While there died one a week, within the liberties.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: No: 'twas within the walls.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Was't so? Cry you mercy:
I thought the liberties. What shall we do now, face?

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Be silent: not a word, if he call, or knock.
I'll into mine old shape again, and meet him,
Of Jeremy, the butler. I' the mean time,
Do you two pack up all the goods, and purchase,
That we can carry i'the two trunks. I'll keep him
Off for today, if I cannot longer: and then
At night, I'll ship you both away to Ratcliffe,
Where we'll meet tomorrow, and there we'll share.
Let Mammon's brass, and pewter keep the cellar:
We'll have another time for that. But, Dol,
Pray thee, go heat a little water, quickly,
Subtle must shave me. All my captain's beard
Must off, to make me appear smooth Jeremy.
You'll do't?

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Yes, I'll shave you, as well as I can.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: And not cut my throat, but trim me?

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: You shall see, sir.
Has there been such resort, say you?

sp.speaker: Nei. 1.
sp.l: Daily, sir.

sp.speaker: Nei. 2.
sp.l: And nightly, too.

sp.speaker: Nei. 3.
sp.l: Ay, some as brave as lords.

sp.speaker: Nei. 4.
sp.l: Ladies, and gentlewomen.

sp.speaker: Nei. 5.
sp.l: Citizen's wives.

sp.speaker: Nei. 1.
sp.l: And knights.

sp.speaker: Nei. 6.
sp.l: In coaches.

sp.speaker: Nei. 2.
sp.l: Yes, and oysterwomen.

sp.speaker: Nei. 1.
sp.l: Beside other gallants.

sp.speaker: Nei. 3.
sp.l: Sailor's wives.

sp.speaker: Nei. 4.
sp.l: Tabacco-men.

sp.speaker: Nei. 5.
sp.l: Another Pimlico!

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: What should my knave advance,
To draw this company? He hung out no banners
Of a strange calf, with five legs, to be seen?
Or a huge lobster, with six claws?

sp.speaker: Nei. 6.
sp.l: No, sir.

sp.speaker: Nei. 3.
sp.l: We had gone in then, sir.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: He has no gift
Of teaching i'the nose, that ere I knew of!
You saw no bills set up, that promised cure
Of agues, or the toothache?

sp.speaker: Nei. 2.
sp.l: No such thing, sir.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Nor heard a drum struck, for baboons, or puppets?

sp.speaker: Nei. 5.
sp.l: Neither, sir.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: What device should he bring forth now!
I love a teeming wit, as I love my nourishment.
Pray god he ha' not kept such open house,
That he hath sold my hangings, and my bedding:
I left him nothing else. If he have eat 'em,
A plague of the moth, say I. Sure he has got
Some bawdy pictures, to call all this ging;

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: Should be today pronounced, to all your friends.
And where be your andirons now? and your brass pots?
That should ha' been golden flagons, and great wedges?

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: Let me but breath. What! they ha' shut their doors,
Mammon and Surly knock. methinks!

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: Ay, now, 'tis holiday with them.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: Rogues,
Cozeners, impostors, bawds.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: What mean you, sir?

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: To enter if we can.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Another man's house?
Here is the owner, sir. Turn you to him,
And speak your business.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: Are you, sir, the owner?

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: And are those knaves, within, your cheaters?

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: What knaves? what cheaters?

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: Subtle, and his lungs.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: The gentleman is distracted, sir! No lungs,
Nor lights ha' been seen here these three weeks, sir,
Within these doors, upon my word!

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: Your word,
Groom arrogant?

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Yes, sir, I am the housekeeper,
And know the keys ha' not been out of my hands.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: This's a new face?

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: You do mistake the house, sir!
What sign was't at?

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: You rascal! This is one
Of the confederacy. Come, let's get officers,
And force the door.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Pray you stay, gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: No, sir, we'll come with warrant.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: Ay, and then,
We shall ha' your doors open.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: What means this?

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: I cannot tell, sir!

sp.speaker: Nei. 1.
sp.l: These are two o'the gallants,
That we do think we saw.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Two of the fools?
You talk as idly as they. Good faith, sir,
I think the moon has crazed 'em all! (Oh me,
The angry boy come too? He'll make a noise,
And never away till he have betrayed us all.)

sp.speaker: Kas.
sp.l: Kastrill knocks. what rogues, bawds, slaves, you'll open the door anon,
Punk, cockatrice, my sister. By this light
I'll fetch the marshal to you. You are a whore,
To keep your castle —

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Who would you speak with, sir?

sp.speaker: Kas.
sp.l: The bawdy doctor, and the cozening captain,
And Pus my sister.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: This is something, sure!

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Upon my trust, the doors were never open, sir.

sp.speaker: Kas.
sp.l: I have heard all their tricks, told me twice over,
By the fat knight, and the lean gentleman.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Here comes another.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Ananias too?
And his pastor?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: The doors are shut against us.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: they beat too, at the door. come forth, you seed of sulphur, sons of fire,
Your stench, it is broke forth: abomination
Is in the house.

sp.speaker: Kas.
sp.l: Ay, my sister's there.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: The place,
It is become a cage of unclean birds.

sp.speaker: Kas.
sp.l: Yes, I will fetch the scavenger, and the constable.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: You shall do well.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: We'll join, to weed them out.

sp.speaker: Kas.
sp.l: You will not come then? punk, device, my sister!

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Call her not sister. She is a harlot, verily.

sp.speaker: Kas.
sp.l: I'll raise the street.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Good gentlemen, a word.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Sathan, avoid, and hinder not our zeal.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: The world's turned bedlam.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: These are all broke loose,
Out of s. kather'nes, where they use to keep,
The better sort of mad-folks.

sp.speaker: Nei. 1.
sp.l: All these persons
We saw go in, and out, here.

sp.speaker: Nei. 2.
sp.l: Yes, indeed, sir.

sp.speaker: Nei. 3.
sp.l: These were the parties.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Peace, you drunkards. Sir,
I wonder at it! Please you, to give me leave
To touch the door, I'll try, an' the lock be changed.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: It mazes me!

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Good faith, sir, I believe,
There's no such thing. 'tis all deceptio visus.
Would I could get him away.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.l: Master captain,Dapper cries out within. master doctor.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Who's that?

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: (Our clerk within, that I forgotten!) I know not, sir.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.l: For god's sake, when will her grace be at leisure?

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Ha!
Illusions, some spirit o'the air: (His gag is melted,
And now he sets out the throat.)

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.l: I am almost stifled —

sp.speaker: (Fac.
sp.l: Would you were altogether.)

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: 'Tis i'the house.
Ha! list.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Believe it, sir, i' the air!

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Peace, you —

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.l: Mine ants grace does not use me well.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: You fool,
Peace, you'll mar all.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Or you will else, you rogue.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: O, is it so? Then you converse with spirits!
Come sir. No more o'your tricks, good Jeremy,
The truth, the shortest way.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Dismiss this rabble, sir.
What shall I do? I am catched.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Good neighbours,
I thank you all. You may depart. Come sir,
You know that I am an indulgent master:
And therefore, conceal nothing. What's your medicine,
To draw so many several sorts of wildfowl?

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Sir, you were wont to affect mirth, and wit:
(But here's no place to talk on't i'the street.)
Give me but leave, to make the best of my fortune,
And only pardon me th'abuse of your house:
It's all I beg. I'll help you to a widow,
In recompense, that you shall give me thanks for,
Will make you seven years younger, and a rich one.
'Tis but your putting on a Spanish cloak,
I have her within. You need not fear the house,
It was not visited.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: But by me, who came
Sooner than you expected.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: It is true, sir.
Pray you forgive me.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Well: let's see your widow.
How! ha' you eaten your gag?

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.l: Yes faith, it crumbled
Away i' my mouth.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: You ha' spoiled all then.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.l: No,
I hope my aunt of fairy will forgive me.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Your ant's a gracious lady: but in troth
You were to blame.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.l: The fume did overcome me,
And I did do't to stay my stomach. Pray you
So satisfy her grace. Here comes the captain.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: How now! Is his mouth down?

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: I! he has spoken!

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: (A pox, I heard him, and you too.) He's undone, then.
(I have been fain to say, the house is haunted
With spirits, to keep churl back.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: And hast thou done it?

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Sure, for this night.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Why, then triumph, and sing
Of face so famous, the precious King
Of present wits.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Did you not hear the coil,
About the door?

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Yes, and I dwindled with it.)

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Show him his aunt, and let him be dispatched:
I'll send her to you.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Well sir, your aunt her grace,
Will give you audience presently, on my suit,
And the captain's word, that you did not eat your gag,
In any contempt of her highness.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.l: Not I, in troth, sir.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Dol like the Queen of fairy. here she is come. Down o'your knees, and wriggle:
She has a stately presence. Good. Yet nearer,
And bid, God save you.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.l: Madam.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: And your aunt.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.l: And my most gracious aunt, god save your grace.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: Nephew, we thought to have been angry with you:
But that sweet face of yours, hath turned the tide,
And made it flow with joy, that ebbed of love.
Arise, and touch our velvet gown.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: The skirts,
And kiss 'em. So.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: Let me now stroke that head,
Much, nephew, shalt thou win; much shalt thou spend;
Much shalt thou give away: much shalt thou lend.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: (Ay, much, indeed.) Why do you not thank her grace?

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.l: I cannot speak, for joy.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: See, the kind wretch!
Your grace's kinsman right.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: Give me the bird.
Here is your fly in a purse, about your neck, cousin,
Wear it, and feed it, about this day seu'night ,
On your right wrist —

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Open a vein, with a pin,
And let it suck but once a week: till then,
You must not look on't.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: No. And, kinsman,
Bear yourself worthy of the blood you come on.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Her grace would ha'you eat no more woolsack pies,
Nor dagger frumenty.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: Nor break his fast,
In heaven, and hell.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: She's with you everywhere !
Nor play with costermongers, at mum-chance, tray-trip.
God make you rich, ( whenas your aunt has done it:) but keep
The gallantest company, and the best games —

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.l: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Gleek and primero: and what you get, be true to us.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.l: By this hand, I will.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: You may bring's a thousand pound,
Before tomorrow night, (If but three thousand,
Be stirring) an' you will.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.l: I swear, I will then.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Your ply will learn you all games.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Have you done there?

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Your grace will command him no more duties?

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: No:
But come, and see me often. I may chance
To leave him three or four hundred chests of treasure,
And some twelve thousand acres of fairy land:
If he game well, and comely, with good gamesters.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: There's a kind aunt! kiss her departing part.
But you must sell you forty mark a year, now:

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.l: Ay, sir, I mean.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Or, gi't away: pox on't.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: I'll gi't mine aunt. I'll go and fetch the writings.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: 'Tis well, away.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Where's Subtle?

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Here. What news?

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Drugger is at the door, go take his suit,
And bid him fetch a parson, presently:
Say, he shall marry the widow. Thou shalt spend
A hundred pound by the service! Now, Queen Dol,
Have you packed up all?

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: And how do you like
The lady pliant?

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: A good dull innocent.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Here's your Hieronimo's cloak, and hat.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Give me 'em.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: And the ruff too?

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Yes, I'll come to you presently.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Now, he is gone about his project, Dol,
I told you of, for the widow.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: 'Tis direct
Against our articles.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Well, we'll fit him, wench.
Hast thou gulled her of her jewels, or her bracelets?

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: No, but I will do't.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Soon at night, my Dolly,
When we are shipped, and all our goods aboard,
Eastward for Ratcliffe; we will turn our course
To Brainford, westward, if thou saist the word:
And take our leaves of this o'erweening rascal,
This peremptory face.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: Content, I'm weary of him.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Tho' haste cause, when the slave will run a wiving, Dol,
Against the instrument, that was drawn between us.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: I'll pluck his bird as bare as I can.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Yes, tell her,
She must by any means, address some present
To th' cunning man; make him amends, for wronging
His art with her suspicion; send a ring;
Or chain of pearl; she will be tortured else
Extremely in her sleep, say: and ha' strange things
Come to her. Wilt thou?

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: My fine flittermouse,
My bird of the night; we'll tickle it at the pigeons,
When we have all, and may unlock the trunks,
they kiss. and say, this's mine, and thine, and thine, and mine —

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: What now, a billing?

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Yes, a little exalted
In the good passage of our stock-affairs.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Drugger has brought his parson, take him in, Subtle,
And send Nab back again, to wash his face.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: I will: and shave himself?

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: If you can get him.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: You are hot upon it, face, whate'er it is!

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: A trick, that Dol shall spend ten pound a month by.
Is he gone?

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: The chaplain waits you i' the hall, sir.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: I'll go bestow him.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: He'll now marry her, instantly.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: He cannot, yet, he is not ready. Dear Dol,
Cousin her of all thou canst. To deceive him
Is no deceit, but justice, that would break
Such an inextricable tie as ours was.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: Let me alone to fit him.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Come, my venturers,
You ha' packed up all? Where be the trunks? Bring forth.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Here.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Let's see 'em. Where's the money?

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Here,
In this.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Mammon's ten pound: eight score before.
The brothers' money, this. Druggers, and dappers.
What paper's that?

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: The jewel of the waiting maids,
That stole it from her lady, to know certain —

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: If she should have precedence of her mistress?

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: What box is that?

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: The fishwives rings, I think:
And th'alewives single money. Is't not Dol?

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: Yes: and the whistle, that the sailors wife
Brought you, to know, and her husband were with ward.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: We'll wet it tomorrow: and our silver-beakers,
And tavern cups. Where be the French petticoats,
And girdles, and hangers?

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Here, i' the trunk,
And the bolts of lawn.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Is Druggers damask, there?
And the tobacco?

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Give me the keys.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: Why you the keys!

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: No matter, Dol: because
We shall not open 'em, before he comes.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: 'Tis true, you shall not open them, indeed:
Nor have 'em forth. Do you see? Not forth, Dol.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: No!

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: No, my smock-rampant. The right is, my master
Knows all, has pardoned me, and he will keep 'em,
Doctor, 'tis true (You look) for all your figures:
I sent for him, indeed. Wherefore, good partners,
Both he, and she, be satisfied: for, here
determines the indenture tripartite,
Twixt Subtle, Dol, and face. All I can do
Is to help you over the wall, of the backside;
Or lend you a sheet, to save your velvet gown, Dol.
Here will be officers, presently; bethink you,
Of some course suddenly to scape the dock:
For thither you'll come else. some knock. hark you, thunder.

sp.speaker: Syb.
sp.l: You are a precious fiend!

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: Open the door.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Dol, I am sorry for thee i'faith. But hearst thou?
It shall go hard, but I will place thee somewhere:
Thou shalt ha' my letter to mistress amo.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: Hang you —

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Or madame Caesarean.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: Pox upon you, rogue,
Would I had but time to beat thee.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Subtle,
Let's know where you set up next; I'll send you
A customer, now and then, for old acquaintance:
What new course ha'you?

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Rogue, I'll hang myself:
That I may walk a greater devil, than thou,
And haunt thee i' the flock-bed, and the buttery.

div.head: Act v. scene v.
div.stage: Love-wit, officers, Mammon, svrly, Face, Kastril, Ananias, tribulation, drugger, Da. Pliant.

sp.l: What do you mean, my masters?

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: Open your door,
Cheaters, bawds, conjurers.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: Or we'll break it open.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: What warrant have you?

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: Warrant enough, sir, doubt not:
If you'll not open it.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Is there an officer, there?

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: Yes, two, or three for failing.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Have but patience,
And I will open it straight.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Sir, ha' you done?
Is it a marriage? perfect?

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Yes, my brain.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Off with your ruff, and cloak then, be yourself, sir.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: Down with the door.

sp.speaker: Kas.
sp.l: 'Slight, ding it open.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Hold.
Hold gentlemen, what means this violence?

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: Where is this collier?

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: And my captain face?

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: These day-owles.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: That are birding in men's purses.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: Madam Suppository.

sp.speaker: Kas.
sp.l: Doxy, my sister.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Locusts
Of the foul pit.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: Profane as Bael, and the dragon.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Worse than the grasshoppers, or the lice of Egypt.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Good gentlemen, hear me. Are you officers,
And cannot stay this violence?

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: Keep the peace.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Gentlemen, what is the matter? Whom do you seek?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: Be patient Ananias.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: I am strong,
And will stand up, well girt, against an host,
That threaten Gad in exile.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: I shall send you
To Amsterdam, to your cellar.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: I will pray there,
Against thy house: may dogs defile thy walls,
And wasps, and hornets breed beneath thy roof,
This seat of falsehood, and this cave of cozenage.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Another too?

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: Not I sir, I am no brother.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Drueger enters, and he beats him away. away you harry Nicholas, do you talk?

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: No, this was Abel drugger. Good sir, go,
And satisfy him; tell him, all is done:
He stayed too long a washing of his face.
The doctor, he shall hear of him at Westchester;
And of the captain, tell him at Yarmouth: or
Some good port-town else, lying for a wind.
If you get off the angry child, now, sir —

sp.speaker: Kas.
sp.l: to his sister. come on, you yew, you have matched most sweetly, ha' you not?
Did not I say, I would never ha' you tupped
But by a dubbed boy, to make you a lady-tom?
'Slight, you are a mammet! O, I could touse you, now.
Death, mun' you marry with a pox?

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: You lie, boy;
As sound as you: and I am aforehand with you.

sp.speaker: Kas.
sp.l: Anon?

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Come, will you quarrel? I will feeze you, sirrah.
Why do you not buckle to your tools?

sp.speaker: Kas.
sp.l: God's light!
This is a fine old boy, as ere I saw!

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: What, do you change your copy, now? Proceed,
Here stands my dove: stoup at her, if you dare.

sp.speaker: Kas.
sp.l: 'Slight I must love him! I cannot choose, i'faith!
And I should be hanged for't. Sister, I protest,
I honour thee, for this match.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: O, do you so, sir?

sp.speaker: Kas.
sp.l: Yes, and thou canst take tobacco, and drink, old boy,
I'll give her five hundred pound more, to her marriage,
Than her own state.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Fill a pipeful, Jeremy.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: Yes, but go in, and take it, sir.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: We will.
I will be ruled by thee in any thing, Jeremy.

sp.speaker: Kas.
sp.l: 'Slight, thou art not hidebound! thou art a Iouy' 'Boy!
Come let's in, I pray thee, and take our whiffs.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Whiff in with your sister, brother boy. That master
That had received such happiness by a servant,
In such a widow, and with so much wealth,
Were very ungrateful, if he would not be
A little indulgent to that servant's wit,
And help his fortune, though with some small strain
Of his own candour. Therefore, gentlemen,
And kind spectators, if I have outstripped
an old man's gravity, or strict canon, think
What a young wife, and a good brain may do:
Stretch age's truth sometimes, and crack it too.
Speak for thyself, knave.

sp.speaker: Fac.
sp.l: So I will, sir. Gentlemen,
My part a little fell in this last scene,
Yet 'twas decorum. And though I am clean
Got off, from Subtle, surly, Mammon, Dol,
Hot Ananias, Dapper, drugger, all
With whom I traded; yet I put myself
On you, that are my country: and this pelf,
Which I have got, if you do quit me, rests
To feast you often, and invite new guests.

div.p: This comedy was first acted, in the year 1610.

The principal comedians were,
Ric. Burbadge.
Joh. Lowin.
Hen. Condel.
Alex. Cooke.
Rob. Armin.
Joh. Hemings.
Will. Ostler.
Joh. Underwood.
Nic. Tooly.
Will. Eglestone.
With the allowance of the master of revels.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
